questions.text: A 55-year-old woman undergoes a routine abdominal CT scan for an unrelated issue. The scan reveals a 2.5 cm mass in the left adrenal gland. The patient has no history of adrenal disorders but reports occasional episodes of sweating and palpitations. Her blood pressure is elevated. Based on these findings, what condition should be primarily ruled out in the diagnostic workup?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ > 5 cm: Surgery recommended due to >25% malignancy risk.
  • ↳ 3-5 cm: Strongly consider surgery. Management depends on imaging features, patient age, surgical risk, tumor growth, and patient preference.
  • ↳ < 3 cm: Observation with follow-up imaging is appropriate.

Imaging

All patients with adrenal incidentalomas should be assessed for malignancy based on the size and imaging characteristics of the mass.
CT differentiates benign cortical adenoma from adrenal carcinoma or metastasis.

 

FNAC

Fine-needle aspiration differentiates adrenal tumors from metastatic tumors.

Biopsy is avoided in suspected pheochromocytomas due to the risk of crisis.

  • FNAC is to be done only after ruling out Pheochromocytoma

Hormonal Evaluation

All patients with adrenal incidentalomas should be assessed for subclinical hormonal hyperfunction.

Pheochromocytoma

24-hour urinary fractionated metanephrines, catecholamines, or plasma fractionated metanephrines

Subclinical Cushing Syndrome

Measure dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and perform 1 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST)

Primary Aldosteronism

Measure plasma aldosterone and plasma renin activity (if hypertension or hypokalemia is present)

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with episodic symptoms of severe headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating. His laboratory tests reveal elevated plasma metanephrines, and a CT scan identifies a vascular adrenal mass. Which of the following statements accurately describes the nature of this adrenal mass?

options.label: A
options.text: Primarily secretes ACTH, causing continuous hypertension.

options.label: B
options.text: It intermittently releases catecholamines, leading to episodes of headache, palpitations, and sweating.

options.label: C
options.text: Presents with chronic, steady symptoms without significant paroxysms.

options.label: D
options.text: Usually non-vascular and causes minimal clinical symptoms.

questions.correct_answer: B. It intermittently releases catecholamines, leading to episodes of headache, palpitations, and sweating.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in her 24th week of pregnancy presents with severe headaches, palpitations, and paroxysmal hypertension. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated plasma metanephrines, and imaging confirms the presence of a pheochromocytoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Use phenoxybenzamine and plan laparoscopic adrenalectomy in the second trimester.

options.label: B
options.text: Wait until the third trimester, use Labetalol to control BP, and perform a C-section followed by adrenalectomy.

options.label: C
options.text: Use calcium channel blockers and plan for surgical resection postpartum.

questions.correct_answer: A. Use phenoxybenzamine and plan laparoscopic adrenalectomy in the second trimester.
questions.explanation:
Biochemical Diagnosis

Identify pheochromocytoma using biochemical tests and imaging for localization.

Preoperative Preparation
  • Start with an α-adrenoceptor blocker like phenoxybenzamine.
  • Adjust the dose to 100-160 mg/day to achieve postural hypotension.
  • Add β-blockers if necessary after α-blockade to manage tachycardia.
  • Other regimens include α-blockade with doxazosin or prazosin, with and without β-blockers, calcium channel blockers alone, and using catecholamine synthesis blocker metyrosine in cardiac failure.

Surgery
  • Laparoscopic Adrenalectomy: Preferred for PCC unless tumor >10 cm or malignant signs are present.
  • Open Surgery: Recommended for large tumors or those along the sympathetic chain.

Postoperative Care
  • Monitor for hypovolemia and hypoglycemia for 24 hrs post-surgery.
  • Conduct annual biochemical tests for recurrence.

Malignant Pheochromocytoma
  • Perform surgical excision, possibly with en bloc resection for invasive tumors.
  • Consider adjuvant therapies like radiolabeled MIBG and octreotide.

Pheochromocytoma in Pregnancy
  • First/Second Trimester: Implement α-blockade, then proceed with laparoscopic adrenalectomy.
  • Third Trimester: Plan for an elective C-section followed by adrenalectomy 6 weeks later.
